#Text=Rice encrusting with small-seeded native species for reintroduction in agroecosystems: a case study in�Lindernia procumbens\rAnna Corli,�Andrea Mondoni,�Francesco Porro,�Graziano Rossi,�Valentina Vaglia,�Micol Orengo,�Simone Pedrini,�Simone Orsenigo\rFirst published: 13 August 2024\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14257\rCitations:�1\rAuthors contributions: AM, SO conceived and designed the research; AC, FP, MO performed the experiments; AC, FP, MO analyzed the data; AC, AM, FP, SP, SO wrote the first draft of the manuscript; all authors provided edits and comments and participated in the revision of to the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Kripal Singh\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Seed coating is commonly applied in agricultural seed industry to alleviate biotic and edaphic barriers and improve seed germination, seedling emergence and establishment.
#Text=Recently, this seed enhancement technology has been tested and applied to seeds of native species for ecological restoration and conservation.
#Text=This work presents a novel application of seed coating for the reintroduction of species with dust-like seeds that render direct seeding and cultivation unfeasible.
#Text=Here we have used seed coating on�Lindernia procumbens�(Krocker) Philcox (Linderniaceae), a threatened annual species of paddy fields.
#Text=�Lindernia procumbens�seeds were encrusted to the surface of rice seeds that acted as carrier to spread the species along rice sowing.
#Text=We first tested how two selected concentrations of binder affected�L. procumbens�germination, then we investigated sowing depth (i.e. surface level�light, and buried�darkness) effect.
#Text=Rice encrusting is a feasible and valuable tool for preserving threatened species with tiny seeds, since binder did not limit�L. procumbens�germination.
#Text=Light increased�L. procumbens�seedlings emergence compared to buried conditions.
#Text=Although�L. procumbens�emergence was limited in a paddy field trial, we promoted the formation of a soil seed bank for the species.
#Text=As such, this should not discourage the possibility to reintroduce rare species with tiny seeds in agroecosystems.

#Text=This pioneering technique can be extended to ecological restoration, where there is an urgent need for new seed-based approaches and seed-coating technologies to improve seedling establishment and restoration efficacy.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Seed coating is largely used in agricultural sectors yet its application in plant conservation is still limited.\r* Seed coating can be applied for preserving threatened species with tiny seeds in agroecosystems, using crop seeds as an efficient and cost-effective carrier for their dissemination.\r* New seed-based technological approaches can have an impact on plant conservation and restoration ecology.\r* Collaborations with engineers, seed producers and farmers are necessary to scale up native seed encrusting on crop seeds for nature conservation; however, significant investment is required in the development of both equipment and procedures.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Seed enhancement technologies are used to improve the establishment of native species within the restoration sector by alleviating biotic and edaphic barriers by reducing seed predation (Taylor et al�2020) or seed loss through displacement (Hosseini et al�2017).

#Text=Seed coating, originally developed for the agricultural and horticultural sectors, is one of the most commonly applied seed enhancement technologies on native species for ecological restoration (Pedrini et al�2020; Brown et al�2021).

#Text=Seed coating relies on covering seeds with fine-grained powders and binders to homogenize their shape and size to improve seed survival (e.g. by protecting from pathogens and predators; Madsen et al�2016) and stress resistance (e.g. salicylic acid, beneficial microbes; Rocha et al�2019; Pedrini et al�2021), while promoting seed germination and plant growth (e.g. nutrients, hormones, plant growth promoters, symbionts).

#Text=Despite the high initial cost and the extensive research required to adapt existing crop seed technologies to the complex and diverse native seed types, there is a growing interest in the restoration ecology community to test seed coating for improving the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of seed-based restoration activities (Pedrini et al�2020).
#Text=However, this technology has rarely been explored for conservation actions.

#Text=This work presents a novel application of seed coating to arable plant conservation, involving�Lindernia procumbens(Krocker) Philcox (Linderniaceae), a threatened herb typical of European agroecosystems (i.e. paddy fields).

#Text=In Europe, where agriculture covers about 40% of the land (Richner et al�2014), vascular plants adapted to arable fields are the most vulnerable to land-use change among European flora (Meyer et al�2013), because of the intensification of agronomic practices toward mechanization, use of chemicals and simplified rotation of the last decades.
#Text=Thus, the preservation of arable species is relevant for biodiversity conservation, particularly in the Old World, where they originated or anciently established (Albrecht et al�2016).

#Text=Traditional agricultural areas are hotspots of arable plant diversity (Fanfarillo et al�2023), with some European countries having up to 77% of the arable flora being classified as threatened (582 species already threatened with extinction across the continent; Storkey et al�2011).

#Text=Arable fields represent also an important�and often the remnant�secondary habitat for rare endemic species, particularly for those regions characterized by the presence of native arable plants and degraded habitats (Sietz et al�2022).

#Text=Indeed, plants strictly linked to agroecosystems do not generally recolonize their original habitat after local extinction, and where populations can escape destruction, they remain confined to relict habitats fragmented in the rural landscape (on farm; Abeli et al�2022).

#Text=Recently, conservation attempts on arable plants have been carried out in Europe, especially in  biodiversity friendly   organic farms where the use of synthetic pesticides and fertilizers is limited and long crop rotations are implemented (G�rzen et al�2021).

#Text=For example, an experimental study conducted in Italian rice fields showed that the threatened species�Marsilea quadrifolia�L., currently restricted to this secondary habitat, is compatible with organic rice cultivation (Corli et al�2021).

#Text=However, the coexistence of threatened plants and crops is possible only if farmers and local stakeholders are involved at an early stage of conservation projects, if adequate training is provided and if conservation efforts are translated into income (Abeli et al�2022).

#Text=Several examples come from different realities: in Belgium, organic farmers participate in reintroducing the endemic�Bromus grossus�Desf. ex DC. by annually sowing a mixture of cereals  contaminated   with the threatened species (Piqueray et al�2018; Abeli et al�2022) while in Italy, the network  Riso Bio Vero   brings together organic rice farmers to discuss agricultural techniques and results, needs and path of innovation jointly with scientists, public officials and the managers of a company distributing organic products (Pagliarino et al�2020; Vaglia et al�2022).

#Text=Conservation actions can often be constrained by species-specific traits, such as life cycle and the small seed dimensions, which render direct seeding and cultivation in nursery prior to translocation (sensu IUCN�2013) logistically unfeasible.
#Text=This is the case of�L. procumbens, a native annual species to Eurasia, occurring on periodically flooded sites, either natural as floodplains or anthropogenic habitats such as paddy fields.
#Text=This species can also be found in Australian areas, whereas it is not reported in America and Africa.
#Text=Asian populations occurring in paddy fields are defined as weeds (i.e.
#Text=Li et al�2012; Chen et al�2017) despite no negative effect on either crop yields or competitive disadvantage on�L. procumbens�has been reported.

#Text=On the other hand, European populations show an opposite trend: the scattered distribution in highly fragmented habitats, the intensive agricultural practices ( umberov� et al�2012) and the competitive disadvantage with the invasive congeneric�Lindernia dubia�(L.)
#Text=Pennell co-occurring in paddy fields (Corli et al�2024), led to a strong decline of�L. procumbens�populations.
#Text=Consequently, the species was included in Annex I of Bern Convention and in Annex IV of the  Habitat   Directive 92/43/EEC, the main conservation framework at EU level.
#Text=Although�L. procumbens�is classified as  Least Concern   on the European Red List (Bilz et al�2011), it is included as a threatened species in several national Red Lists.
#Text=In Italy, where the species is classified as Data Deficient (Rossi et al�2016), new occurrences have been recently found in organic paddy fields.

#Text=The conservation of this species is mandatory at the EU level; however, conservation efforts are constrained since the species is annual and displays dust-like seeds (0.35   0.16 mm; Ghimire et al�2017; 0.003 g/seed; A.
#Text=Corli 2024, personal observation).

#Text=With the idea to spread the threatened species in paddy fields using an efficient and cost-effective conservation action,�L. procumbens�seeds were attached directly to the surface of rice seeds (that acted as a carrier) using a technique called encrusting (Pedrini et al�2017), instead of directly increase seeds size through pelleting, as is commonly done for small-seed agricultural species (e.g. tobacco, begonia).

#Text=To test the effectiveness and applicability of this novel approach for species conservation, we first tested whether the binder used to perform the encrusting process had a negative effect on�L. procumbens�germination by applying different binder concentrations.
#Text=Then, considering that rice seeds are normally buried when sown, we tested the effect of darkness on seedlings emergence of�L. procumbens�encrusted on rice seeds.
#Text=Lastly, we conducted a field trial in a paddy field to assess if encrusting rice seeds is a viable approach that ensure the conservation of this threatened species.
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Seed Encrusting\rSeeds of�L. procumbens�were manually collected in 2020 in a paddy field (Pavia province, Northern Italy) at the time of natural dispersal (i.e. end of July).
#Text=Seeds were cleaned and stored in the Germplasm Bank of the University of Pavia at 15 degrees C and 15% Relative Humidity (RH).
#Text=Seeds of�L. procumbens�were encrusted on rice seeds using polyvinyl alcohol (hereafter, PVOH) as a binding agent.
#Text=Polyvinyl alcohol is a polymer of both natural and synthetic origin that provides adherence and cohesion of material onto the seed.

#Text=Due to limited�L. procumbens�seeds availability and the need to ensure that an exact number of seeds was applied to each grain of rice for testing germination outcomes, the encrusting process was performed manually.

#Text=Polyvinyl alcohol solutions were prepared for each experimental test (i.e. two germination and emergence trials in laboratory and one in paddy field) according to the range of recommended concentration commonly used for seed coating (Sekisui Specialty Chemicals�2023).

#Text=The solutions were prepared by heating 1 L of distilled water to 90 degrees C and slowly adding a selected amount of PVOH, stirring continuously with a mechanical stirrer for about 30 minutes until the solutions were homogeneous.
#Text=After cooling, rice seeds were wet with the PVOH solution and then placed on baking paper.
#Text=A selected number of seeds of�L. procumbens�were then added on top of rice grains; after drying, seeds encrusted were used for the experimental tests.

#Text=Seed Germination and Seedling Emergence in Laboratory\rThe effect of PHOV on�L. procumbens�seed germination (i.e. number of emerged radicles out of the number of seed sown) was tested in February 2021.

#Text=We selected two concentrations of PVOH (i.e. 5% and 10%) to identify which would have the least detrimental effect on germination by adding 50 and 100 g of PVOH to 1 L distilled water, respectively.

#Text=After cooling, 120 rice seeds (60 for each concentration) were individually immersed within 5% and 10% PVOH concentrations and 5 seeds of�L. procumbens�were added manually with a metal tweezer on each rice seed (Fig�1A).
#Text=Germination test was carried out by sowing 6 replicates of 10 encrusted rice seeds per concentration on 1% distilled water�agar held in Petri dishes.

#Text=Plates were placed in an incubator (LMS 250A, LMS Ltd., Sevenoaks, U.K.) at the optimum germination temperature (i.e. 30   degrees C; Corli et al�2024) and at 12-h daily photoperiod (photosynthetically active radiation 40�50  mol m 2 s 1).
#Text=�Lindernia procumbens�germination was monitored at 4-day intervals; germination test lasted for 15 days and was interrupted when a drastic reduction in seeds germination was observed.
#Text=The germination percentage of encrusted seeds was compared with the germination of�L. procumbens�in the absence of PVOH (i.e. control).
#Text=Figure 1\rSeed coating with�Lindernia procumbens.
#Text=(A)�Lindernia procumbens�seeds encrusted on the surface of rice seeds.
#Text=(B) Seedlings establishment in the growth chamber and (C) in paddy field.
#Text=The threatened species already bloomed, is highlighted with the arrow, next to rice plants.
#Text=The effect of darkness on�L. procumbens�seedling emergence (i.e. number of fully emerged cotyledons out of the number of seed sown) from rice-encrusted seed was tested on March 2022.

#Text=Although 10% PVOH concentration provided a slightly higher germination of�L. procumbens, we decided to use 5% PVOH because of faster drying, less viscous and thinner film, which makes seed encrusting easier and more convenient.
#Text=In this case, rice seeds were encrusted with 10�L. procumbens�seeds each using a metal tweezer.

#Text=Seedling emergence tests were carried out by sowing encrusted seeds in 2 trays with 104 cells each (1 encrusted seed cell 1) at either surface level (i.e. 0 cm, light) or buried (i.e.  2 cm, darkness).

#Text=Trays were put in a growth chamber at constant temperature and relative humidity (T = 30   degrees C, RH = 70%); trays were filled with peat based soil (Tercomposti S.P.A., Calvisano (BS), Italy) and placed in basins with water level kept constant at 2 cm, aiming to simulate the usual water level of paddy fields (Fig�1B).

#Text=Seedling emergence was monitored at 3-day intervals within the first 3 weeks, then weekly until the end of the experiment; the test lasted for 50 days until no additional seedling emergence was observed.
#Text=During the monitoring, emerged rice seeds were cut at the node level as the growing rice plant would not fit inside the growth chamber and to facilitate the observation of�L. procumbens.
#Text=For this experiment, seedlings survival was also monitored.
#Text=Seedling Emergence of Encrusted Seeds in Paddy Fields.

#Text=The effect of PVOH on�L. procumbens�seedling emergence (i.e. number of fully emerged cotyledons out of the number of seed sown) in paddy field was tested at the  Riserva San Massimo   farm (Pavia province, Northern Italy).
#Text=We sow 10 kg of encrusted rice seeds in a 150-m2�plot chosen at the edge of the paddy field, applying a similar seeding rate used by the farmer (i.e. 180�200 kg ha 1).
#Text=Seed coating was performed with 5% PVOH concentration.

#Text=Considering the amount of rice and�L. procumbens�to be encrusted, rice seeds were not immersed individually in the solution, rather mixed in a small bowl with 5% PVOH solution;�L. procumbens�seeds were spread on top using a fine mesh sieve.
#Text=As the available total weight of�L. procumbens�seeds used was 22.35 g, we estimated an average of 10�L. procumbensseeds encrusted on each rice seed.
#Text=Encrusted seeds were sown in paddy field at the beginning of May 2022 in line with the usual sowing time of the crop species.

#Text=While rice seeds are typically sown by dry broadcasting with a seeder in rows at 15 cm distance, the sowing of the encrusted seeds was performed manually by dry broadcasting to avoid the potential effect of wasting the encrusted seeds (especially of�L. procumbens) caused by shaking of the seeder; after 1 month, the field was watered and water level was kept constant during the entire vegetative season.
#Text=On 12 August 2022, we conducted a survey in the selected area to evaluate seedling emergence of�L. procumbens�(Fig�1C).
#Text=Data Analysis.

#Text=The effect of PVOH (factorial variable with three levels: i.e. control, 5% PVOH, 10% PVOH) on�L. procumbens�germination was analyzed with a generalized linear mixed model (GLMM) with binomial error structure and logit-link function where the final germination (i.e. number of emerged radicles out of the number of seed sown) was the fixed effect; replicates (i.e. 6) and rice ID (i.e. 10) were considered as nested random effects.
#Text=The effect of darkness (factorial variable with two levels: i.e. 0 cm�light,  2 cm�darkness) on seedlings emergence and seedlings survival of�L. procumbens�was analyzed in similar fashion.

#Text=Significance of differences in final seeds germination and seedlings emergence percentage between the applied conditions tested (i.e. presence/absence of PVOH for the former, presence/absence of light for the latter) were assessed by Tukey's post hoc honest significant difference method (HSD) tests.
#Text=Seedling emergence of�L. procumbens�in paddy field was not analyzed statistically but described in the text.
#Text=Generalized linear mixed models were run with�glmerfunction in the lme4 package (Bates et al�2015); models' assumptions were checked using the DHARMa package (Hartig & Lohse�2022).
#Text=Statistical analyses were performed with R 3.3.0 (R Core Team�2022).
#Text=Results.
#Text=The highest final seed germination percentage was observed at 10% PVOH (Fig�2A).

#Text=Although seed germination with 5% PVOH (37.8 +/- 3.7%) was significantly lower (estimate:  0.45,�p-value = 0.028) than that with 10% PVOH (54.7 +/- 3.6%), it did not vary significantly between the control (50.3 +/- 4.3%) and PVOH treatments.

#Text=Figure 2\rMean + SE of (A) Final seeds germination percentage of�Lindernia procumbens�seeds in the absence of PVOH (control), PVOH at 5% and at 10% and (B) seedlings emergence percentage in the presence (surface) and absence (buried) of light.
#Text=Letters indicate significant differences between treatments according to the Tukey's post hoc HSD tests.

#Text=Light promoted seedling emergence of�L. procumbens, with a significantly higher emergence (4%, i.e. 40 seedlings) for soil surface sown seeds (estimate: 1.52,�p-value <0.001) than to the ones sown at  2 cm deep (1%, i.e. 9 seedlings; Fig�2B).

#Text=On the other hand, there were no differences of seedlings survival between seedlings emerging from the soil surface (i.e. 29 out of 40 seedlings, 72%) or from buried seeds (i.e. 7 seedlings, 77%).
#Text=The data obtained from the field survey confirmed the low germination ability of�L. procumbens, as only 20 seedlings were observed in the paddy field (i.e. less than 0.01% of the seeds sown).
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Our results showed that PVOH does not limit the germination of�L. procumbens�seeds; therefore, it can be successfully applied to small-seeded species.

#Text=The field survey reported a low seedling emergence, likely due to the inhibitory effect of darkness on seed germination (see also Corli et al�2024) and/or the failure of germinated seeds to further develop into seedling (i.e. radicle plus cotyledon emergence).
#Text=Nevertheless, the outcome of this study should not discourage the possibility of conserving and reintroducing a rare species with tiny seeds into the agroecosystem.
#Text=Indeed, on a larger scale (i.e. 1 ha), this will result in more than a thousand�L. procumbens�seedlings ha 1.

#Text=Moreover, with this technique, we have contributed to the formation of the soil seed bank for the species, which is of crucial importance for the persistence of annual species, even more than perennial ones (Gioria et al�2020).

#Text=�Lindernia procumbens�is known to produce a large number of seeds and display a large seed bank, with a number of emerged seedlings ranging between tens and hundreds on 1 m2�( umberov� et al�2012).

#Text=This formation could also ensure seeds germination in the following years as well as a more consistent population, since experimental studies demonstrated the ability of the species to survive in a soil seed bank for at least 7�9 years, even in unsuitable conditions (i.e. deep submersion, dry substrate, or dense cover by perennial vegetation;  umberov� et al�2012).
#Text=Rice encrusting with a threatened species characterized by tiny seeds is thus a feasible and valuable tool that can help in preserving threatened species in agroecosystems.

#Text=Although we did not evaluate the effects of�Lindernia�on rice yield, we have not observed any mortality in the rice plants originated from encrusted seeds and/or received any productivity loss feedback from the farmer.

#Text=This is probably due to the small stature of the species (up to 20 cm,  umberov� et al�2012, compared to the rice cultivar, i.e. mean 114 cm, Enterisi�2024), its ephemeral life cycle (it takes few weeks to grow from seedling to adult plant) and limited abundance (e.g. number of seedlings emerged).

#Text=Nevertheless, conservation measures of arable plants are species- and site-specific, being dependent on the species involved (both crop and wild) and on the agronomic techniques the farmers apply (e.g. plowing, grooming).

#Text=Potentially, this technique can be exported in other similar cases of plant conservation in agroecosystems, where the chosen species can provide different benefits to the farmer and the whole society (e.g. indicator species, ecosystem services, attractiveness of the landscape, ad hoc financial incentives through the EU Rural Development Plan or in terms of local tourism and economy; Abeli et al�2022).

#Text=In this way, farmers could directly safeguard biodiversity, taking part to a trend that is becoming increasingly popular in Europe, as conservation attempts on arable plants are receiving more and more attention (G�rzen et al�2021).

#Text=More generally, our results may have important implications in the context of ecological restoration that is becoming an integral part of conservation planning and implementation (Volis�2019), including researchers, practitioners, decision-makers and community leaders.

#Text=Ecological restoration programs are already performed globally and are increasingly relevant in Europe, with the recent adoption of the Nature Restoration Law (June 2024;�https://environment.ec.europa.eu/topics/nature-and-biodiversity/nature-restoration-law_en).

#Text=Within ecological restoration, there is an urgent need for new seed-based approaches and seed-coating technologies for improving seedling establishment and overall restoration efficacy (Pedrini et al�2023).

#Text=Indeed, seed-coating techniques are still mostly confined to the agrochemical industry that is specialized on agricultural and horticultural species, despite the potential benefits of such treatment for improving species conservation and restoration effectiveness (Pedrini et al�2017).
#Text=These activities are still at their infancy and involve simplified small-scale approaches (e.g. laboratory mixers or shakers, manual coatings, seeds shaken in plastic bags; Pedrini et al�2023).

#Text=Collaboration with engineers and seed producers is essential if such an innovation is to be used as a standardized tool in the native seed supply chain for both conservation activities and restoration practices.

#Text=Significant investment is required in the development of equipment and procedures, but as the needs for ecological restoration and consequent demand for native seed are expected to rise, native seed industry should respond accordingly, and advanced seed technology solutions are expected to become an economic imperative (Pedrini et al�2020).
#Text=Acknowledgments.

#Text=The authors A.C., A.M., and S.O. were funded by the  National Biodiversity Future Center NBFC  National Recovery and Resilience Plan (NRRP), Mission 4 Component 2 Investment 1.4�Call for tender No. 3138 of 16 December 2021, rectified by Decree n.3175 of 18 December 2021 of Italian Ministry of University and Research funded by the European Union�Next Generation EU, Project code CN_00000033.
#Text=The authors would like to thank the farmer D.
#Text=Massignani that kindly offered his farm for the field trial.
#Text=Thanks are also due to F.
#Text=Ferrari, L.
